poem:
The Conundrum

Beneath the orange trees—  
children, not yet full grown,  
stand in line, shadows of dawn,  
shouldering burdens meant for  
others, absent,  
lost in the sweep of xenophobic winds.  
Their small hands  
tremble, picking what remains.  
The sun rises,  
work uninterrupted,  
America, is this your dream?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Alarm as Florida Republicans move to fill deported workers’ jobs with children: ‘It’s insane, right?’ Beneath the smugness of Ron DeSantis, at Florida leading the nation in immigration enforcement lies something of a conundrum: how to fill the essential jobs of the scores of immigrant workers targeted for deportation. The answer, according to Florida lawmakers, is the state’s schoolchildren, who as young as 14 could soon be allowed to work overnight shifts without a break". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
